name: Anonymous
com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

>>9478706
>at some point
Common CPUs have included programmable logic for many years. Nothing like a Cyclone V but le ebik retro hardware memeulation just isn't as popular as some people imagine. Including CPUs in FPGAs is very common. Those have been available to the masses for many years. The masses just aren't that into your edge case hobby.

It sounds like your problem is that you've bought into the mistercoper dogma that FPGAs are just programmable ASICs and can do everything can exactly the same. This is not only false, but laughably so for FPGAs that cost less than a car. No amount of wikipedia reading or kiddo quoting will change this. I'm sure you're aware that many have tried.

If you want hardware emulation get a mister. If you're a bandwagoner who missed the chance to get one a bit cheaper then sucks to be you. But if you wait around for a PC that has a "mister" built into the CPU you're going to be waiting a long time. Because the edge case is you.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: is this really shilling holy fuck its been like 2 weeks and this thread is still up shut the fuck up

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9479574
The "programmable" logic is chicken bits which is basically the same as giving you options for configuring the hardware to do one of N programmed presets, but that's not true reprogrammability. I work in the fucking field so you're not telling me anything new about FPGA CPU combos which Xillinx does better. I'm also not arguing the viability of the masses wanting FPGAs directly but it's the fact that at some point, it will be needed due to the end of Moore's law on the performance front.
FPGAs aren't just programmable ASICs, the name tells you as much. But the applications where FPGAs can't apply like analog where you can't just get it to emulate a photonic processor or temperature sensor are only relevant issues in industrial fields which we aren't talking about and which emulation doesn't actually need. The I/O options given are to alleviate that shortcoming. I don't disagree that it will take a while to get them put into general purpose CPUs but that they will happen at some point and that is when they actually get cheap. Until then, you are right that it's the MISTer or nothing until Terasic decides to move away from the Cyclone V and subsidize something else.

>>9478232
The majority of MMC NES games used 128KB or 256KB carts. Most mega drive games are under 1MB. SMW and A Link to the Past are about 512KB and 720KB respectively. The most popular SNES and MD games weren't anywhere close to the maximum capacity of 4MB. Those carts were expensive as shit. The only games where they're a necessity are fighting games and squeenix cinematic jarpigs.
>And speaking as an Amiga owner, you usually had to wait for most of that 880KB to load before you got to play anything which was easily 1-2 minutes.
I don't remember the loading screens taking that long. You didn't wait for the whole floppy to load, most game were split into opening screen, game data, and level data chunks. The intro music alone could take up to 300KB while level themes were normally 96KB or less. But even if I had to wait 2 minutes for a game to load, I'd rather do that than waste 50 quids or 60 american 90s dollars on a video game. Most console owners rented their games like poorfags and had to pay for a game genie cart and the game mags that had the codes. Amiga bros could grab a game for free and get some cracktro trainer cheats as a bonus. I pity console peasants.

name: Anonymous
com:
Someone posted this image on /ck/ and it reminded me how much I hated pre-rendered backgrounds in 3d games as a kid. Growing up with the SNES and Genesis, I remember the first game we got in 3D was Mario 64, which gives you a very physical, tactile environment where your character interacts with every surface and edge. Then you play something like Zelda or Final Fantasy of the same generation and you get these weird environments where you never feel like your character collides with anything, like your character is running around in a clear box with invisible walls and there is a background superimposed via green screen. As I got older and understood why it was made that way I appreciated the effort and extra detail allowed by it, but as a kid it always bugged me and still does to a degree.

Did this bother anyone else as a kid or just me?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: I barely noticed them as a kid and now think they're gorgeous as an adult, there's nothing quite like them visually. i dont mind the player/environment disconnect that bugs you but a lot of games do a good job of minimizing it--a lot of ffvii does feel like running around and not quite "slotting in" to the environment but then ffix in comparison feels pretty darn seamless.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: It looked great on my TV. Obviously on most emulator settings it looks bizarre. But I do remember these prerendered OOT backgrounds looking very realistic and detailed as opposed to most low poly interiors in the game.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9479341
yeah, N64 emulators in particular make them look awful.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: My first experience with OoT was at the store, with Link running around Hyrule town. I thought it was an awful way to play the game and wondered why they didn't just put the camera behind Link. Obviously a minute later I ran into an actual 3D area and it was better, but then I hated the disconnect of the graphical quality. The game should have be actual 3D with consistent graphics the whole way through, even if the camera is locked somewhere, which it should generally avoid.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9478982
at risk of outing myself as a zoomer, I'll share my lil anecdote
For context, my first time really playing OOT was with the collectors disc bundled with the gamecube around 2003. So by then I was aware that the game was older but I still enjoyed it as if it was new, I was playing my n64 up until that point anyways.
First time I walked into hyrule castle town, even on a CRT I recognized that it looked "bad" as in the image was clearly not the highest quality, but it wasnt jarring at all.
As an adult having went back and played FF7, I love the pre rendered backgrounds but that shit is jarring and actually gets in the way of gameplay sometimes. OOT is a lot more subtle and doesnt try to do too much, which I think helps

I disagree, there are cultures, probably more now than ever, they're just more and more splintered and less and less prone to mass media carpeting through traditional channels, and so they end up being small things to the general public but large things under that surface. This is because the internet has made it easier than ever to find and like something new, but because the systems by which you find them are so splintered, it feels like nothing is solid, because we are used to old ways of thinking about fame and notoriety. When we were growing up, shit wasn't important unless it was on TV, in movies, on albums, or in magazines. Now there is no reason to appear in any of those, because you can do far more with the digital age and reach way more people than in the slowly dying traditional platforms. There are so many net cultures, however, that it's very hard to point at one and say "that's it, that's the biggest thing right now". Its like that kardashian slut on SNL a few months ago. She rightly called being on TV a "small, intimate setting" because TV is the modern newspaper; Nobody important is on TV anymore, they're on shit like instagram and tiktok. Yet her game came from being on TV and in tabloids and such, which is why it seems like everyone knows about her. The problem is that even if TV is increasingly irrelevant, and culture is explosing online, a generation like ours either generally avoids social media, or just because of the weird ways you have to find your space in those worlds, we simply miss them. Tons of people use different social media platforms, and yet they mean completely different things to those people, because it is easy for someone or something to be famous yet unknown due to their being in a small subset of that service or platform.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9479057
As such I argue that rather than no culture, there's actually too much subculture, buried away on different platforms and in different corners, and because it's all famous to somebody, but lacks penetration on the old world media empires (TV, film, records, print) it remains "unknown" to anyone outside of the right circles. That's why it feels like there is no culture, because the traditional modes that have dominated pop culture are outmoded and irrelevant, and because the new cultures are built for "somebody, but not everybody" which means they don't get picked up and pushed as part of a "mainstream" culture. It's a bizarre duality that's difficult to explain.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9479060
It does explain, however why the old media empires seem to do nothing but rely on old fucks, like Tom Cruise doing another fucking top gun. They don't know who of the young world is actually going to fit their "wide movie audience" or whatever, and so they just go back to old shit that benefited from the age when people got all their fame through old world media bombardment. As for the lack of "scenes" or the accusation of only using trappings of old scenes as costumes, my understanding is that young people are generally much less interested in the tribalism of being specific to one scene or identity, in part because people are so easily exposed anymore to new things. It's not like you have to subscribe to a certain magazine or go to specific stores in order to find out about stuff. With everything being online, and costing only time to find out about, why close yourself off to new things you might like, simply for sake of definition? It's almost more a modern rejection of the idea that corporate products can define your personality or sensibilities, and a willingness to stay open to new ideas or experiences, though I don't think shallow means of self-identity have disappeared in teens, they gave just changed foci and forms of expression. I don't pretend to be an expert on the subject however.

>>9471906
According to Kim Newman in the book Nightmare Movies (2011), the "zombie revival began in the Far East" during the late 1990s, largely inspired by the Japanese zombie games Resident Evil and The House of the Dead. The success of these two 1996 zombie games inspired a wave of Asian zombie films, such as Bio Zombie (1998) and Versus (2000), for example.[18] The zombie revival which began in the Far East eventually went global following the worldwide success of Japanese zombie games such as Resident Evil and The House of the Dead. Their success led to a wave of Western zombie films during the 2000s, such as 28 Days Later (2002) and Shaun of the Dead (2004), for example.[18] In 2013, George Romero said it was the video games Resident Evil and House of the Dead "more than anything else" that popularised his zombie concept in mainstream popular culture.[19][20]

The House of the Dead has also been credited with introducing a new type of zombie distinct from Romero's classic slow zombie: the fast running zombie. After first appearing in The House of the Dead, they became popular in zombie films and video games during the 2000s, including the Resident Evil games and films, The House of the Dead film adaptation, and the films 28 Days Later (2002) and Dawn of the Dead (2004).[21]

>Diddy Kong Racing
Dumbest course-select screen in the history of video games. Marred by some shitty story mode and collectathon elements because Rare can't help themselves. Course design not great
>Crash Team Racing
Lacks the charm of Mario, samey visuals, items aren't as intuitive and leaving you guessing what they really do and, similar to DKR, dumb story mode to unlock important stuff

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9464058
I'll be honest, when I was in my 20s, Raiden was a big turn-off for me compared to MGS1 as Snake. I don't think he was a good fit for a series at the time was taken as a spy/james bond type game primarily played by guys who liked that sort of thing. It was especially a bait to play as Snake for an hour before being thrown into Raiden's shoes without warning for the rest of the game.

I also didn't like the characters as much as MGS1 except for Solidus, the Liquid living on through an arm transplant to Ocelot was beyond stupid and just got even worse through MGS4, your support staff was overall more bland and less interesting than MGS1 (I get that Colonel was to be an AI recreation and thus his advice and personality are supposed to be flat, but still), Fortune and Vamp were completely over the top, and Fatman was good but silly didn't fit the theme. MGS3 had its fair share of camp, but still felt more grounded overall than MGS2.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9464109
I think it also has to do with just age. There's a lot of games that wouldn't get the time of day on release because there were better ones that you'd spend your limited time on. Fast forward fifteen years and now when games release at a glacial pace and are unappealing to older audiences who grew up with video games, now suddenly games that weren't regarded well on release get more attention because the landscape is starved for fresh entertainment.

I recently started playing through the PSX library and started quite a few games that I saw but passed on during its lifetime because I couldn't play everything at once and found myself enjoying them. There's nothing modern I'd rather play, so I'm perfectly content playing something that decent but not great because it's still a type of game I'd want to play over the latest PS5 releases.

Sort of true, but sort of not. It was a dumb framebuffer with 2 CPUs which makes it "easy" in that there was no cumbersome hardware to learn how to operate, but that meant you did everything in hand tuned assembly which to most people is harder than learning how to draw stuff with VDP1/2. The Saturn had the same CPU model but clocked higher and so if you did find this easy you could do the same on Saturn, negating any pro/con. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9477616
No. There shouldn't be seller protection on an internet based market. You're dealing with the entire world as the seller. Any sense of responsibility goes out the window. It's trivial for someone to run a scam as a seller, through multiple accounts as needed.

If you want seller protection then you need to run a limited market. In the real world this is handled by geography, a store has to deal with its community at the end of the day. On the internet this is handled by just limiting the clientele to a specific niche. This is why there are smaller markets for things like trading cards that exist outside of ebay. A seller on those markets has protection but is held to higher standards. Said marketplace might go out of its way to protect sellers AND give complainers a refund while keeping the product because those limited marketplaces can afford to watch trends.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>9476901
No.
You are thinking of Street Fighter Zero that was created to make use of CPS1 boards exchanged to Capcom for CPS2 games.
Then Capcom execs sabotaged this plan by decided to make SFZ a CPS2 game at the last second.
Source: Yoshiki Okamoto's youtube commentaries.

I figure the CPS1 repurposing project eventually resulted in the creation of the CPS Changer project, which got a version of the original CPS1 version of SFZ.

That's right, the common lore that Capcom created a "special version" SFZ for the Changer is incorrect. The CPS1 is the original and the CPS2 is the special version.

ST was an early CPS2 game and there would have been no reason for Capcom to need to get rid of surplus boards at that time. I've never heard of it being a limited release either. It was extremely hyped and popular upon release in Japan, contrary to (incorrect) western lore that continues to hound the legacy of the game.
